properties.description:
CHANGAN

CHINA

The starting point of the Silk Road. Formerly the capital of the Han, Sui, and Tang dynasties, it is located near the present-day city of Xian.

DUNHUANG

CHINA

Dunhuang is situated at a point of vital strategic and logistical importance, at the crossroads of two major trade routes within the Silk Road network.

LOULAN

CHINA

Loulan was an ancient kingdom based around an important oasis city along the Silk Road already known in the 2nd century BCE on the northeastern edge of the Lop Desert. It was intermittently under Chinese control from the early Han dynasty onward until its abandonment centuries later.

KASHGHAR

CHINA

Kashgar was an isolated oasis on the long trade route across the Asian continent that lies in far western China. It was a major hub along the great Silk Road as the northern and southern Silk Routes crossed here and caravans departed for Central Asia, India, Pakistan, and ancient Persia (current Iran).

SAMARKAND

UZBEKISTAN

Samarkand has been at the crossroads of world cultures for over two and a half millennia and is one of the most important sites on the Silk Routes traversing Central Asia. Located in the Zerafshan River valley, in north-eastern Uzbekistan, the city enjoys the benefits of abundant natural resources.

BUKHARA

UZBEKISTAN

Situated on an oasis in central Uzbekistan, Bukhara lies at the crossroads of ancient trade routes that stretched across Central Asia. It was one of the most prosperous cities throughout the Middle Ages, and became a centre for trading, culture, and scholarship. Bukhara also contributed many locally produced goods and was particularly renowned for its textile industry.

MERV

TURKMENISTAN

Merv, located near an oasis in Turkmenistan, was conquered by a series of empires vying for control of the Silk Road's heart. It is the oldest and most preserved city along the historical Silk Road. A few buildings and structures constructed in the last two millennia still stand today. UNESCO has listed the site of ancient Merv as a World Heritage Site.

MASHHAD

IRAN

Mashhad is situated in the north-east of Iran, on a natural corridor that runs along the borders with Afghanistan and Turkmenistan between two mountain belts. Mashhad is the second largest city in Iran and is a centre of industry, commerce, and learning. It provided a vital resting point and a trading centre for the many merchants who enriched Mashhad with their goods and ideas.

TEHERAN

IRAN

Tehran is the capital of Iran, in the north of the country. Iran, also known as Great Persia, played an important role as it is located between the east and the west of the world. The flourishing time of the silk road in Iran was during the 3rd to 7th centuries, when this empire gained its main wealth by exchanging products for silk.

PALMYRA

SYRIA

The remains of the ancient Palmyra stand in the middle of the desolate desert in Syria. The city was well-served to become an important centre of trade for those merchants who chose to cross this desert rather than take the longer route around it, and a hub of cultures and languages as well.

ALEPPO

SYRIA

Aleppo has stood at the crossroads of trade routes across Syria since at least the 3rd millennium BC. It is the largest city in Syria, and is situated on a plateau in the northwest of the country, and the Euphrates River to the east, a location that has kept Aleppo at the centre of international communication and commerce.

ANTIOCH

TURKEY

Its ruins lie near the current city of Antakya, Turkey, to which the ancient city lends its name. Antioch, as a hub crossing of north-south and east-west trade routes, was occupied by Pompey in 64 BCE and quickly became an important Roman military, commercial, and cultural center.

ISTANBUL

TURKEY

From the 4th century onwards, the Rome to which all roads led in the Mediterranean world was Constantinople. Renamed Istanbul under the Turks, the city again became the capital of a great empire and played a central role in east-west cultural and economic exchange.

VENICE

ITALY

Its strategic position on the shores of the Adriatic Sea, within reach of the Byzantine Empire and traders from the Near East, allowed the city to become a hub of trade in the west, receiving goods from the east by sea and disseminating them into the growing European market.

ROME

ITALY

The Silk Road carried goods and ideas between the two great civilizations of Rome and China. Silk was once a favourite of the Roman Empire's wealthy and noble citizens. The demand for silk has continued to increase steadily over the centuries. The Roman Empire benefited from the commerce created by the route along the Silk Road.

VALENCIA

SPAIN

The city was founded on the banks of the River Turia in 138 BC by the Romans, and began to prosper in the Andulasian period (714-1171). The advent of Islamic culture brought with it a myriad of trading activities related to paper, silk, leather and ceramics and placed Valencia as a commercial hub.

PORTO

PORTUGAL

Porto is the second-largest city in Portugal and one of the Iberian Peninsula major urban areas. Located on the Atlantic coast, was therefore at the fringe of the Silk Road. Iberian Peninsula played in the development of cultural, economic and social relations along the Silk Routes.
